dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, the Trump administration and that post-Brexit UK really kicked off this deglobalization trend, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, the Trump administration and that post-Brexit U K really kicked off this deglobalization trend, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Initially driven by wealthy countries namely, the United States under former President Donald Trump and the United Kingdom following the Brexit referendum several geopolitical forces have combined to accelerate the shift toward deglobalization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And then you had COVID lockdowns just hammering global supply chains, especially in China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And then you had COVID lockdowns just hammering global supply chains, especially in China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: COVID-19-related lockdowns and closures have disrupted global supply chains and shut down major production centers, most notably in China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and now with the war in Ukraine, it's like trade routes are totally upended. Western countries are scrambling for new sources of oil, gas, wheat...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and now with the war in Ukraine, it's like trade routes are totally upended. Western countries are scrambling for new sources of oil, gas, wheat...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, the war in Ukraine has altered trade routes and forced Western countries to find alternative suppliers of major commodities like oil, gas, wheat, and fertilizers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and those sanctions on Russia? They've sent food and energy prices through the roof. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and those sanctions on Russia? They've sent food and energy prices through the roof. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Western-led sanctions on Russia have further impeded trade and sharply increased food and energy prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But what's really wild is how financial markets are still super integrated despite all this. Cross-border capital flows are just, like, totally unregulated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what's really wild is how financial markets are still super integrated despite all this. Cross-border capital flows are just, like, totally unregulated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while global trade could become even more fragmented if major economies adopt protectionist policies such as border carbon taxes, financial markets remain strongly integrated. Cross-border capital flows are still largely unregulated and more volatile than ever.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that's hitting low- and middle-income countries hard. All that 'hot money' from the 90s liberalization—it's making them super vulnerable to capital flight now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's hitting low- and middle-income countries hard. All that 'hot money' from the 90s liberalization-it's making them super vulnerable to capital flight now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The liberalization of capital accounts in these countries in the 1990s has led to large inflows of hot money: private financial capital driven not so much by developing countries economic outlook as by developed countries macroeconomic policies. Over the years, the inflows of hot money, often held as reserves and invested in low-return dollar assets, have made emerging and developing economies vulnerable to capital flight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially with the Fed and EU hiking rates so fast. It's crushing these countries with external debt, forcing them to raise their own rates even more aggressively.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially with the Fed and E U hiking rates so fast. It's crushing these countries with external debt, forcing them to raise their own rates even more aggressively.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The rapid interest-rate hikes in the US and the European Union have compounded low- and middle-income countries external debt burdens, forcing them to raise interest rates even more aggressively than advanced economies and hindering their recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, isn't even stopping foreign investors from pulling out. Their currencies are tanking, labor markets are suffering...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, isn't even stopping foreign investors from pulling out. Their currencies are tanking, labor markets are suffering...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, these dramatic rate hikes have not prevented fickle foreign investors from fleeing, causing emerging-market currencies to depreciate and severely damaging labor markets and growth prospects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not like these rate hikes are fixing inflation in developed countries either. They're risking recessions without tackling the real issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not like these rate hikes are fixing inflation in developed countries either. They're risking recessions without tackling the real issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the developed countries combination of higher interest rates and fiscal consolidation is counterproductive, as it risks causing recessions without addressing the real forces behind surging inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So developing nations are stuck mimicking policies that don't work for them. They need tailored solutions—price controls on key goods, boosting domestic production...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So developing nations are stuck mimicking policies that don't work for them. They need tailored solutions-price controls on key goods, boosting domestic production...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead of mimicking developed countries ineffective approach, developing and emerging countries must introduce policies tailored to their specific needs and political economies. Such policies include controlling the prices of key commodities, increasing domestic production to alleviate critical shortages, and ensuring social protections for the newly unemployed and those who are worst affected by high inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And stronger capital controls, for sure. To curb those volatile portfolio flows that cause currency depreciation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And stronger capital controls, for sure. To curb those volatile portfolio flows that cause currency depreciation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Above all, developing countries must introduce more effective capital controls. Imposing constraints on volatile portfolio flows, particularly those that contribute to currency depreciation, is crucial to mitigating the risks associated with financial globalization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, breaking free from the dollar-dominated system, like some are doing with Russia sanctions. Regional cooperation is key.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, breaking free from the dollar-dominated system, like some are doing with Russia sanctions. Regional cooperation is key.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, just as several developing countries have explicitly or implicitly defied the US-led trade sanctions on Russia, policymakers must break free from the US-dominated international financial system, especially dollar swaps and repo markets. Given that most developing countries cannot afford to act on their own, regional cooperation is also critical.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the UNCTAD report mentioned South-South clearing unions. If trade grows among Global South economies, they can settle in their own currencies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the U N C T A D report mentioned South-South clearing unions. If trade grows among Global South economies, they can settle in their own currencies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The United Nations Conference on Trade and Developments annual report mentions several innovative forms of finance and exchange payments that Global South countries could implement to counter advanced economies financial dominance, including South-South clearing unions. If trade among Global South economies grows quickly, the report notes, the flows will be settled in their own currencies or through regional currency mechanisms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That could help with debt restructuring, regional financial insurance... even stabilization funds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That could help with debt restructuring, regional financial insurance... even stabilization funds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such mechanisms could also help negotiate debt-restructuring deals, provide financial insurance at the regional level, and even establish stabilization funds to improve countries foreign-asset positions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Financial globalization was supposed to help them, but it's done the opposite. Now deglobalization might be their chance to regain some control.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Financial globalization was supposed to help them, but it's done the opposite. Now deglobalization might be their chance to regain some control.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Financial globalization was supposed to usher in an era of robust growth and fiscal stability in the developing world. It ended up doing the opposite.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Embracing the fragmentation could actually restore their economic viability, weirdly enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Embracing the fragmentation could actually restore their economic viability, weirdly enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, to restore their economic viability, low- and middle-income countries must make the most of deglobalization and embrace the fragmentation of international capital markets.
